elements.content: While metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or, more generally, coordination polymers (CPs) built using linkers possessing two different functional groups are known very well in the literature, the effect of a third functional group on the physico­chemical properties of those materials is weakly recognized. To study this issue we designed an amino­carboxy­phosphonic ligand, 3-amino-5-(dihydroxy­phosphoryl)­benzoic acid (H 3 APB), which is an amino derivative of meta-phosphono­benzoic acid. By self-assembly with a copper­(II) source, we obtained the three-dimensional CP {[Cu3­(APB)2­(H2O)6]·​6H2O} n , 1, featuring rare binodal 4,5-connected tcs topology. By comparison with previously known representatives of that topology, we put forward a hypothesis that CPs of rare topologies, such as tcs, are obtained when polytopic, differentially substituted ligands are used. The structure of 1 is layered, but not in the manner typical for “traditional” metal phosphonates and carboxy­phosphonates, and it was found to be flexible; structural flexibility has been demonstrated by dehydration–hydration experiments. The structural changes were probed with the use of PXRD and IR methods. We have also shown that the copper­(II) amino­carboxy­phosphonate 1 presented herein has moderate capability for degradation of methylene blue, rhodamine B, and acridine orange in oxidizing conditions; however, the rate of dye degradation is greatly enhanced under visible light irradiation. Analysis of magnetic properties revealed that 1 is a spin-frustrated system with a diamond-chain arrangement of copper­(II) ions. The magnetic data were fitted using the isotropic Heisenberg as well as Ising models. Both models consistently indicate that magnetic exchange paths are both antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic, with dominating participation of the former interaction.
elements.clean_text: While metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or, more generally, coordination polymers (CPs) built using linkers possessing two different functional groups are known very well in the literature, the effect of a third functional group on the physicochemical properties of those materials is weakly recognized. To study this issue we designed an aminocarboxyphosphonic ligand, 3-amino-5-(dihydroxyphosphoryl)benzoic acid (H  3  APB), which is an amino derivative of meta-phosphonobenzoic acid. By self-assembly with a copper(II) source, we obtained the three-dimensional CP {[Cu3(APB)2(H2O)6]⋅6H2O} n , 1, featuring rare binodal 4,5-connected tcs topology. By comparison with previously known representatives of that topology, we put forward a hypothesis that CPs of rare topologies, such as tcs, are obtained when polytopic, differentially substituted ligands are used. The structure of 1 is layered, but not in the manner typical for "traditional" metal phosphonates and carboxyphosphonates, and it was found to be flexible; structural flexibility has been demonstrated by dehydration-hydration experiments. The structural changes were probed with the use of PXRD and IR methods. We have also shown that the copper(II) aminocarboxyphosphonate 1 presented herein has moderate capability for degradation of methylene blue, rhodamine B, and acridine orange in oxidizing conditions; however, the rate of dye degradation is greatly enhanced under visible light irradiation. Analysis of magnetic properties revealed that 1 is a spin-frustrated system with a diamond-chain arrangement of copper(II) ions. The magnetic data were fitted using the isotropic Heisenberg as well as Ising models. Both models consistently indicate that magnetic exchange paths are both antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic, with dominating participation of the former interaction.

elements.content: Organic ligands used for the generation of the vast majority of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) or, more generally, coordination polymers (CPs) have one or two different binding groups attached. The choice of functional group imparts certain physico­chemical properties and structural preferences to the resulting CP; however, combination of different functional groups may yield additional, unexpected features. We examine the properties of copper­(II) CPs constructed from ligands possessing three different groups: amino, phosphonic, and carboxylic. Structural and topological studies as well inputs from magnetic characterization, visible-light dye photo­degradation, and hydration−dehydration experiments are reported and discussed.
elements.clean_text: Organic ligands used for the generation of the vast majority of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or, more generally, coordination polymers (CPs) have one or two different binding groups attached. The choice of functional group imparts certain physicochemical properties and structural preferences to the resulting CP; however, combination of different functional groups may yield additional, unexpected features. We examine the properties of copper(II) CPs constructed from ligands possessing three different groups: amino, phosphonic, and carboxylic. Structural and topological studies as well inputs from magnetic characterization, visible-light dye photodegradation, and hydration-dehydration experiments are reported and discussed.

elements.content: A vast majority of the research on coordination polymers (CPs) has been primarily concentrated on coordination assemblies of polytopic carboxylic acids and heterocyclic bases with various metal ions, mostly divalent and trivalent ones. The interest in CPs increased significantly when it became clear that this class of materials is promising in applications such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, and drug delivery, due to facile formation of porous networks. Independently, several other classes of CPs were also developed, among them, metal phosphonates (MPs). Those hybrid materials, featuring the presence of a phosphonic group (−PO3H2), were found to have properties significantly different than those of carboxylate analogues; e.g., they have a strong tendency to form dense structures in which the ligand is pendant in the interlayer space or serves as a pillar between the layers, unless an additional bulky base is incorporated or a π-extended ligand is used. Dense structure, which usually results in improved thermal and chemical properties of such materials, is a direct consequence of the phosphonic group’s ability to form stable, highly connected metal clusters. Indeed, the coordination chemistry of this group is much richer than that of other binding groups, owing to three available protonation states (un­deprotonated, mono­deprotonated, and bi­deprotonated) and the presence of a plethora of coordination modes, both bridging and chelating.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A vast majority of the research on coordination polymers (CPs) has been primarily concentrated on coordination assemblies of polytopic carboxylic acids and heterocyclic bases with various metal ions, mostly divalent and trivalent ones. The interest in CPs increased significantly when it became clear that this class of materials is promising in applications such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, and drug delivery, due to facile formation of porous networks. Independently, several other classes of CPs were also developed, among them, metal phosphonates (MPs). Those hybrid materials, featuring the presence of a phosphonic group (-PO3H2), were found to have properties significantly different than those of carboxylate analogues; e.g., they have a strong tendency to form dense structures in which the ligand is pendant in the interlayer space or serves as a pillar between the layers, unless an additional bulky base is incorporated or a π-extended ligand is used. Dense structure, which usually results in improved thermal and chemical properties of such materials, is a direct consequence of the phosphonic group's ability to form stable, highly connected metal clusters. Indeed, the coordination chemistry of this group is much richer than that of other binding groups, owing to three available protonation states (undeprotonated, monodeprotonated, and bideprotonated) and the presence of a plethora of coordination modes, both bridging and chelating.

elements.content: Because metal carboxylates and phosphonates are noticeably different in their characteristics, it is natural to investigate the properties of ligands possessing both functional groups. Indeed, CPs constructed from various phosphono­benzoic acids (3-(dihydroxy­phosphoryl)­benzoic acid and its analogues are presented in ) were found to combine the structural rigidity and coordination preferences of participating functional groups, leading to interesting applications such as robust luminescent materials, release of silver, and proton conduction.
elements.clean_text: Because metal carboxylates and phosphonates are noticeably different in their characteristics, it is natural to investigate the properties of ligands possessing both functional groups. Indeed, CPs constructed from various phosphonobenzoic acids (3-(dihydroxyphosphoryl)benzoic acid and its analogues are presented in ) were found to combine the structural rigidity and coordination preferences of participating functional groups, leading to interesting applications such as robust luminescent materials, release of silver, and proton conduction.

elements.content: Given the advances in carboxy­phosphonate chemistry, we decided to open up the field of aromatic amino­carboxy­phosphonates by incorporation of an amino group into the benzene scaffold, since the effect of that group on coordination preferences and properties has been scarcely recognized to date. The structure of a ligand designed for this purpose, 3-amino-5-(dihydroxy­phosphoryl)­benzoic acid (H 3 APB), is presented in . By reaction with copper­(II) salt, we obtained a three-dimensional CP, 1, featuring structural flexibility, which has been proved by hydration–dehydration experiments; moreover, the presence of “diamond chains” of copper­(II) ions allowed us to characterize its spin-frustrated magnetic properties. Finally, we examined the capability of copper­(II) amino­carboxy­phosphonate to photo­degrade dyes under visible light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: Given the advances in carboxyphosphonate chemistry, we decided to open up the field of aromatic aminocarboxyphosphonates by incorporation of an amino group into the benzene scaffold, since the effect of that group on coordination preferences and properties has been scarcely recognized to date. The structure of a ligand designed for this purpose, 3-amino-5-(dihydroxyphosphoryl)benzoic acid (H  3  APB), is presented in . By reaction with copper(II) salt, we obtained a three-dimensional CP, 1, featuring structural flexibility, which has been proved by hydration-dehydration experiments; moreover, the presence of "diamond chains" of copper(II) ions allowed us to characterize its spin-frustrated magnetic properties. Finally, we examined the capability of copper(II) aminocarboxyphosphonate to photodegrade dyes under visible light irradiation.

elements.content: H 3 APB was synthesized according to a previously reported multistep method. All analytical grade chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Compound 1 was synthesized at ambient conditions. The solution of CuSO4·5H2O (69.0 mg, 0.0276 mmol) in water (6 mL) was mixed with a solution of H 3 APB (10.0 mg, 0.046 mmol) in water (2 mL). The obtained clear mixture was left for slow evaporation for 3 days after which green crystals were filtrated and air-dried. Elemental analysis calcd for C14H34Cu3N2O22P2: C, 20.14; H, 4.07; N, 3.35; found: C, 20.3; H, 3.8; N, 3.5. Compound 1 is not soluble in water and methanol, but is easily dissolved in warm N,N-dimethyl­formamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and N,N-dimethyl­acetamide (DMA), suggesting the decomposition of coordination network. The phase purity of bulk sample of 1 was established by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), since the experimental pattern agreed well with the simulated one (vide infra).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Synthesis of 1 

 H  3  APB was synthesized according to a previously reported multistep method. All analytical grade chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Compound 1 was synthesized at ambient conditions. The solution of CuSO4⋅5H2O (69.0 mg, 0.0276 mmol) in water (6 mL) was mixed with a solution of H  3  APB (10.0 mg, 0.046 mmol) in water (2 mL). The obtained clear mixture was left for slow evaporation for 3 days after which green crystals were filtrated and air-dried. Elemental analysis calcd for C14H34Cu3N2O22P2: C, 20.14; H, 4.07; N, 3.35; found: C, 20.3; H, 3.8; N, 3.5. Compound 1 is not soluble in water and methanol, but is easily dissolved in warm N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), suggesting the decomposition of coordination network. The phase purity of bulk sample of 1 was established by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), since the experimental pattern agreed well with the simulated one (vide infra).

elements.content: PXRD patterns of the CP was measured on a PANanalytical X’Pert diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54182 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using a NETZSCH STA 449 F3 Jupiter thermoanalyzer coupled with a quadrupole QMS 403 C Aëolos mass spectrometer, in the range 20–800 °C at a heating rate 5 °C/min in flowing nitrogen–oxygen (80:20) atmosphere. Mid-infrared (MIR) spectra were obtained on a VERTEX 70V FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker Optik GmbH, Ettlingen, Germany) in attenuated total reflection (ATR) measurement mode. Elemental analysis was performed on an Elemental vario EL III apparatus.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization Methods

PXRD patterns of the CP was measured on a PANanalytical X'Pert diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54182 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using a NETZSCH STA 449 F3 Jupiter thermoanalyzer coupled with a quadrupole QMS 403 C Aëolos mass spectrometer, in the range 20-800 °C at a heating rate 5 °C/min in flowing nitrogen-oxygen (80:20) atmosphere. Mid-infrared (MIR) spectra were obtained on a VERTEX 70V FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker Optik GmbH, Ettlingen, Germany) in attenuated total reflection (ATR) measurement mode. Elemental analysis was performed on an Elemental vario EL III apparatus.

elements.content: The obtained single crystal of 1 was used for data collection on a four-circle KUMA KM4 diffractometer equipped with a two-dimensional CCD area detector. Graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and the ω-scan technique (Δω = 1°) were applied, while additional data collection and reduction, along with absorption correction, were performed using the CrysAlis software package. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, revealing the positions of all or almost all non-hydrogen atoms. The remaining atoms were located as a result of subsequent difference Fourier syntheses. The structure was refined using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms connected to carbon atoms were constrained as a riding model. The positions of the H atoms of water molecules were located on a difference Fourier map, where possible, and constrained. The collection parameters, crystallographic data, and final agreement parameters are listed in . Selected geometrical parameters are listed in Table S1. The hydrogen-bonding geometry for 1 is listed in Table S2. Visualization of the structures was conducted using the Diamond program, while a topological simplification of coordination networks was performed with the ToposPro package. Geometrical features of intermolecular interactions were determined with the help of Platon software.

Graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and the ω-scan technique (Δω = 1°) were applied, while additional data collection and reduction, along with absorption correction, were performed using the CrysAlis software package. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, revealing the positions of all or almost all non-hydrogen atoms. The remaining atoms were located as a result of subsequent difference Fourier syntheses. The structure was refined using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms connected to carbon atoms were constrained as a riding model. The positions of the H atoms of water molecules were located on a difference Fourier map, where possible, and constrained. The collection parameters, crystallographic data, and final agreement parameters are listed in . Selected geometrical parameters are listed in Table S1. The hydrogen-bonding geometry for 1 is listed in Table S2. Visualization of the structures was conducted using the Diamond program, while a topological simplification of coordination networks was performed with the ToposPro package. Geometrical features of intermolecular interactions were determined with the help of Platon software.

Magnetic susceptibility down to 1.7 K at field of 100 mT was measured with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic correction (−130 × 10–6 emu mol–1 per Cu ion) was calculated using Pascal’s constants. The parameters of theoretical models were fit in the temperature range 1.7–280 K, because the last two experimental points (at 290 and 300 K) deviated slightly from the trend line. The exchange Hamiltonian in the form H = −JS 1 S 2 was used consistently throughout the paper. All values of magnetization and magnetic susceptibility are reported per one mole of metal ion.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Magnetic susceptibility down to 1.7 K at field of 100 mT was measured with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic correction (-130 × 10-6 emu mol-1 per Cu ion) was calculated using Pascal's constants. The parameters of theoretical models were fit in the temperature range 1.7-280 K, because the last two experimental points (at 290 and 300 K) deviated slightly from the trend line. The exchange Hamiltonian in the form H = -JS 1 S 2 was used consistently throughout the paper. All values of magnetization and magnetic susceptibility are reported per one mole of metal ion.

elements.content: Dehydration was carried out by placing a vial containing 1 in a vacuum desiccator loaded with phosphorus­(V) oxide. The sample was kept under these conditions until it reached stable mass. Sample was removed and analyzed using PXRD and IR methods. Afterward the sample was placed in a chamber in the presence of water and after it reached stable mass was analyzed again using the aforementioned characterization methods.
elements.clean_text:
Dehydration-Rehydration Experiments

Dehydration was carried out by placing a vial containing 1 in a vacuum desiccator loaded with phosphorus(V) oxide. The sample was kept under these conditions until it reached stable mass. Sample was removed and analyzed using PXRD and IR methods. Afterward the sample was placed in a chamber in the presence of water and after it reached stable mass was analyzed again using the aforementioned characterization methods.

elements.content: The photocatalytic activity of 1 was evaluated by photodegradation of rhodamine B (RhB), acridine orange (AO), and methylene blue (MB) dyes using visible light at room in open air and at room temperature in the presence of oxidizing agent (H2O2). In a typical run, 1 mg of 1 was added into 10 mL of respective dye aqueous solution (85–120 ppm) in a 20 mL vial. Next, the suspension was magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 min to ensure the adsorption–desorption equilibrium. After equilibration, 0.5 mL of 5% H2O2 was added to the mixture solution. The suspension was then illuminated by a Optel HP-250 polarized-light lamp (Optel, Opole, Poland). During the visible light irradiation, stirring was maintained to keep the mixture in suspension, and 0.5 mL portions of suspension were taken at 20–40 min intervals and filtered through 0.2 μm nylon syringe filters. Absorption spectra of filtrates in the UV–vis region were acquired using a Jasco V-670 spectrophotometer in 1 cm quartz cuvettes.
elements.clean_text:
Dye Degradation Experiments

The photocatalytic activity of 1 was evaluated by photodegradation of rhodamine B (RhB), acridine orange (AO), and methylene blue (MB) dyes using visible light at room in open air and at room temperature in the presence of oxidizing agent (H2O2). In a typical run, 1 mg of 1 was added into 10 mL of respective dye aqueous solution (85-120 ppm) in a 20 mL vial. Next, the suspension was magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 min to ensure the adsorption-desorption equilibrium. After equilibration, 0.5 mL of 5% H2O2 was added to the mixture solution. The suspension was then illuminated by a Optel HP-250 polarized-light lamp (Optel, Opole, Poland). During the visible light irradiation, stirring was maintained to keep the mixture in suspension, and 0.5 mL portions of suspension were taken at 20-40 min intervals and filtered through 0.2 μm nylon syringe filters. Absorption spectra of filtrates in the UV-vis region were acquired using a Jasco V-670 spectrophotometer in 1 cm quartz cuvettes.

elements.content: H 3 APB was prepared according to the synthetic procedure presented by us. Vividly green crystals of compound 1 were afforded by simple evaporation of water solution of H 3 APB and copper sulfate at ambient conditions. X-ray diffraction studies revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in a triclinic space group P1̅. This compound forms three-dimensional neutral framework and is represented by a formula {[Cu3­(APB)2­(H2O)6]·​6H2O} n . The asymmetric unit for 1 comprises one and a half of copper­(II) cations, one ligand residue, three coordination water molecules, and three lattice water molecules (Figure S1). Ligand moiety is triply deprotonated. Bond distances in both phosphonic and carboxylic groups confirm deprotonation of them: 1.515(3)–1.526(3) Å for P–O bonds and 1.232(6) and 1.280(5) Å for C7–O4 and C7–O5 bonds, respectively. While the distances of P–O bonds are very similar due to formation of coordination bond by each of oxygen atoms, the difference of C–O bond lengths results from coordination of O5 to Cu2. The difference in C–O bond lengths in copper­(II) CPs has been reported previously. In order to adjust to the coordination environment of Cu2 cation, the carboxylic group is not coplanar with the aromatic ring but C4–C3–C7–O4 torsion angle takes value of 24.0(2)°. Carboxylic group tilting of around 20° has been noted for other meta-carboxy­phosphonates and corresponding derivatives; however, flat conformations are also present for sterically noncongested carboxy­phosphonic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structure

 H  3  APB was prepared according to the synthetic procedure presented by us. Vividly green crystals of compound 1 were afforded by simple evaporation of water solution of H  3  APB and copper sulfate at ambient conditions. X-ray diffraction studies revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in a triclinic space group P1̅. This compound forms three-dimensional neutral framework and is represented by a formula {[Cu3(APB)2(H2O)6]⋅6H2O} n . The asymmetric unit for 1 comprises one and a half of copper(II) cations, one ligand residue, three coordination water molecules, and three lattice water molecules (Figure S1). Ligand moiety is triply deprotonated. Bond distances in both phosphonic and carboxylic groups confirm deprotonation of them: 1.515(3)-1.526(3) Å for P-O bonds and 1.232(6) and 1.280(5) Å for C7-O4 and C7-O5 bonds, respectively. While the distances of P-O bonds are very similar due to formation of coordination bond by each of oxygen atoms, the difference of C-O bond lengths results from coordination of O5 to Cu2. The difference in C-O bond lengths in copper(II) CPs has been reported previously. In order to adjust to the coordination environment of Cu2 cation, the carboxylic group is not coplanar with the aromatic ring but C4-C3-C7-O4 torsion angle takes value of 24.0(2)°. Carboxylic group tilting of around 20° has been noted for other meta-carboxyphosphonates and corresponding derivatives; however, flat conformations are also present for sterically noncongested carboxyphosphonic ligands.

elements.content: Compound 1 is an interesting example of coordination plasticity of copper ions. Indeed, Cu1 cation resides on the center of symmetry and at first glance appears to be four-coordinated with a square planar coordination environment. Its coordination sphere is filled with oxygen atoms from two inversion-related phosphonic groups (O2) and oxygen atoms from two inversion-related water molecules (O6). Nonetheless, closer examination of coordination surroundings of Cu1 cation reveals the presence of quite distant water molecules based on oxygen atom O7 (Cu1···O7 distance equals 2.518(6) Å. Consideration of them yields elongated, tetrahedrally distorted octahedral {CuO6} coordination sphere of Cu1 cation (a). Those cations are aligned along [100] direction. The Cu2 cation is a five-connected node with severely distorted square pyramid geometry. Apical position is occupied by O8 oxygen atom from water molecule, while basal positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from two symmetry-related phosphonic groups, one carboxylic oxygen atom (O5) and one nitrogen atom, giving {CuO4N} coordination sphere (b). Overall, each ligand residue is a center which coordinates to five copper­(II) cations.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 is an interesting example of coordination plasticity of copper ions. Indeed, Cu1 cation resides on the center of symmetry and at first glance appears to be four-coordinated with a square planar coordination environment. Its coordination sphere is filled with oxygen atoms from two inversion-related phosphonic groups (O2) and oxygen atoms from two inversion-related water molecules (O6). Nonetheless, closer examination of coordination surroundings of Cu1 cation reveals the presence of quite distant water molecules based on oxygen atom O7 (Cu1⋅⋅⋅O7 distance equals 2.518(6) Å. Consideration of them yields elongated, tetrahedrally distorted octahedral {CuO6} coordination sphere of Cu1 cation (a). Those cations are aligned along [100] direction. The Cu2 cation is a five-connected node with severely distorted square pyramid geometry. Apical position is occupied by O8 oxygen atom from water molecule, while basal positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from two symmetry-related phosphonic groups, one carboxylic oxygen atom (O5) and one nitrogen atom, giving {CuO4N} coordination sphere (b). Overall, each ligand residue is a center which coordinates to five copper(II) cations.

elements.content: One can distinguish a structural subunit which is formed by coordination of two Cu2 species by two ligand residues via carboxylic and amino groups (c). Dimeric unit obtained in this way yields R4,2(14) ring motif. Four of such subunits are connected throughout two coordination bonds (Cu2–O3 and Cu2–O1) creating an R­(4,2)­8 motif whose recurrence further leads to formation of a layer parallel to the (010) plane (). Within that molecular sheet two additional motifs can be found, engaging phosphonic and amino functional groups (R4,2(14) motif), and involving phosphonic and carboxylic groups (R4,2(16) motif). Adjacent layers are connected with each other by Cu1 cations, thus extending the structure into a three-dimensional framework (). The distance between these layers is equal to 8.654(3) Å.

elements.content: The structure of 1 has common coordination features with recently published cobalt­(II) CP based on trifunctional 5-(dihydroxyphosphoryl)­nicotinic acid. In this CP, crystallized in P1̅ space group, molecules of the ligand analogously form centrosymmetric dimeric units by bridging via cobalt­(II) ion, with the difference that they are held by coordination to phosphonic group and pirydinium nitrogen (instead of carboxylic and amino ones). As a result, the ring motif is contracted to R4,2(12). Among the three crystallographically distinct cobalt­(II) ions two of them participate in formation of layers, which are further fastened together with remaining octahedral cobalt­(II) ion (in 1 the same function is served by Cu1). Void spaces are also filled with lattice water. We think that those structural details are common since 5-(dihydroxyphosphoryl)­nicotinic acid is the closest trifunctional analogue of H 3 APB, and therefore has similar coordination preferences.

elements.content: Hydrogen bonds (HBs) play a supplementary role to the coordination network. In this rather complex supramolecular net 15 HBs of varying strength can be distinguished (see Table S2 and Figure S2); five of the HBs come from coordination water molecules (based on oxygen atoms O7 and O8), while the rest provide anchor for lattice water molecules residing in the channels of the material. Water molecule centered at O9 oxygen atom participates in four HBs (as acceptor, N1–H11···O9, O7–H72···O9; and as donor, O9–H91···O10, O9–H92···O5). The other two crystallization water molecules (O10 and O11 oxygen atoms) are connected to the framework via five and three HBs, respectively (for O10: O6–H62···O10, O8–H81···O10, O9–H91···O10, O10–H101···O4, O10–H102···O8, for O11: O11–H111···O8, O11–H112···O6, O11–H112···O11).

elements.content: Topological analysis proved to be a valuable tool for classification, simplification, and understanding of complex structures, such as compound 1. In the first attempt of simplification we obtained three-nodal coordination net described by net point symbol (4.62.83)­(4.62)­(42.62.82) wherein (4.62.83), (4.62), and (42.62.82) notations correspond to P1, phenyl scaffold itself, and Cu1, respectively. A closer examination of that net reveals that the former two nodes can be merged into one; in result a rare binodal 4,5-connected tcs topology is obtained. This topology is featured by the (44.62)­(44.66) point symbol, in which the (44.62) and (44.66) notations come from the 4-connected Cu1 and 5-connected ligand nodes, respectively. In all calculations hydrogen bonds were not considered as topological paths. It is worth noting that Cu2 cation is not topologically distinct node (because is two-connected) and thus serves only as a linker.
elements.clean_text:
Topology

Topological analysis proved to be a valuable tool for classification, simplification, and understanding of complex structures, such as compound 1. In the first attempt of simplification we obtained three-nodal coordination net described by net point symbol (4.62.83)(4.62)(42.62.82) wherein (4.62.83), (4.62), and (42.62.82) notations correspond to P1, phenyl scaffold itself, and Cu1, respectively. A closer examination of that net reveals that the former two nodes can be merged into one; in result a rare binodal 4,5-connected tcs topology is obtained. This topology is featured by the (44.62)(44.66) point symbol, in which the (44.62) and (44.66) notations come from the 4-connected Cu1 and 5-connected ligand nodes, respectively. In all calculations hydrogen bonds were not considered as topological paths. It is worth noting that Cu2 cation is not topologically distinct node (because is two-connected) and thus serves only as a linker.

elements.content: Intrigued by rare topological architecture we obtained, we decided to check how already known CPs of tcs net are constructed (all found CPs are collected in ). As can be seen, most of tcs CPs are synthesized from two different types of ligands (entries 1–5). In those CPs poly­(carboxylic acid)­s and bridging N-heterocyclic bases (i.e., bis­(4-pyridylformyl)­piperazine) as coligands are used. The same effect on topology is obtained when a flexible ligand is used for synthesis, but CP must incorporate two crystallographically distinct conformers of the ligand (entry 6).

Abbreviations: 3-bpmp = bis­(3-pyridylmethyl)­piperazine, H4pyro = pyromellitic acid, H2pht = phthalic acid, bpfp = bis­(4-pyridylformyl)­piperazine, 1,2,4-H3BTC = 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylic acid, ppene = 4-pyr-poly-2-ene, dia = 9,10-di­(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­anthracene, oba = 4,4′-oxybisbenzoate, hmph = homophthalate, bpfp = bis­(4-pyridylformyl)-piperazine, HDAM = N,N′-diacetic acid imidazolium.

A separate strategy exists for CPs based on one polytopic ligand. Gu et al. described three isostructural CPs prepared from 5-(6-carboxypyridin-3-yl)­isophthalic acid (cpia, entry 7). A general similarity of this ligand to H 3 APB needs to be stressed in two respects: both ligands are of low symmetry as well as possess many binding sites (cpia has three carboxylic groups and one pirydinyl). We found only one example of CP of tcs topology, which is constructed from relatively simple building units (entry 8).

elements.content: Based on inputs presented above, we put forward a hypothesis that complex topologies such as tcs can be accessed not only by a combination of two (and possibly more) polytopic ligands possessing large number of binding sites, but also by exploitation of a ligand which is differentially substituted with binding groups. Indeed, we achieved this goal using amino, carboxylic, and phosphonic functional groups. This idea seems to be quite intuitive as it is evident that coordination preferences of various functional groups are indeed differentwhich is the result of coordination geometry and possible coordination modes (compare for example in this respect carboxylic and phosphonic groups).

elements.content: Looking at the structure from the point of view of magnetic interactions between copper centers, the crystal structure of 1 is featured by copper trimers Cu1Cu2Cu2 held by a single phosphonic group. Another μ3-PO3 group links both the Cu2 atoms with the next Cu1 atom, giving the chain along the [110] axis. Two adjacent Cu2 atoms are connected by double O1–P1–O3 bridges forming a chair-type eight-membered ring with the short metal–metal distance 4.479 Å. The bridges joining Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are not symmetric: d(Cu···Cu) = 5.446 Å for the Cu1–O2–P1–O1–Cu2 and 5.126 Å for Cu1–O2–P1–O3–Cu2 linkages. This type of chain has been named a trimerized spin chain (TSC) or distorted diamond chain (DDC), “distorted” comes from the fact that the exchange parameters J 1 and J 3 may be different (). The neighboring chains are connected by long bridges provided by the organic ligand Cu1–O–P–C–C–C–N–Cu2, d(Cu···Cu) = 6.661 Å. Such a long contact mediated by six atoms suggests, that any interchain exchange interactions are very weak.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Looking at the structure from the point of view of magnetic interactions between copper centers, the crystal structure of 1 is featured by copper trimers Cu1Cu2Cu2 held by a single phosphonic group. Another μ3-PO3 group links both the Cu2 atoms with the next Cu1 atom, giving the chain along the [110] axis. Two adjacent Cu2 atoms are connected by double O1-P1-O3 bridges forming a chair-type eight-membered ring with the short metal-metal distance 4.479 Å. The bridges joining Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are not symmetric: d(Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu) = 5.446 Å for the Cu1-O2-P1-O1-Cu2 and 5.126 Å for Cu1-O2-P1-O3-Cu2 linkages. This type of chain has been named a trimerized spin chain (TSC) or distorted diamond chain (DDC), "distorted" comes from the fact that the exchange parameters J 1 and J 3 may be different (). The neighboring chains are connected by long bridges provided by the organic ligand Cu1-O-P-C-C-C-N-Cu2, d(Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu) = 6.661 Å. Such a long contact mediated by six atoms suggests, that any interchain exchange interactions are very weak.

elements.content: The diamond chain systems attract the attention of researchers, as the model of quantum spin system with geometrical spin frustration leading to competing exchange interactions. The model compounds containing diamond chains are azurite Cu3(CO3)2(OH)2 and dolerophanite Cu2OSO4, other examples are also known.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of 1 is shown in and as χ–1 and the effective magnetic moment per Cu ion versus T [μeff = 2.828­(χT)1/2]. The susceptibility does not obey the Curie–Weiss law, and the approximate values of the moment and the Weiss constant are 2.13 μB and −19 K in the temperature range 100–200 K, and 2.33 μB and −60 K in 200–280 K. The effective magnetic moment decreases to 1.84 μB at 20 K and then to 1.09 μB at 1.7 K. The M(B) curve increases monotonically with growing field, reaching a value of 0.46 μB at 5 T. At about 4 T a weakly marked inflection point is visible.

elements.content: Magnetic properties of S = 1/2 DDC have been analyzed using the isotropic Heisenberg as well as the Ising model. It is well known that in the case of copper­(II) compounds the Heisenberg model is preferred. Meanwhile, we obtained a surprisingly good fit of the experimental data of 1 and the susceptibility values calculated using the Ising model, so we decided to present and compare the results obtained for both approaches.

It is well known that in the case of copper(II) compounds the Heisenberg model is preferred. Meanwhile, we obtained a surprisingly good fit of the experimental data of 1 and the susceptibility values calculated using the Ising model, so we decided to present and compare the results obtained for both approaches.

elements.content: The susceptibility of DDC in Ising model is given according to : χ ∥ = ( N g 2 β 2 2 k T ) ( A B ) in which A = U exp­(K 2)­[4 exp­(K +) + cosh­(K +) + exp­(−2K 2)] – 4­[cosh­(K +) – cosh­(K –)] and B = 2U, with U = exp­(K 2) cosh­(K +) + exp­(−K 2) cosh­(K –) + 2 cosh­(K 2), K ± = (J 1 ± J 3)/2kT, K 2 = J 2/4kT, and the parameters N, β, g, k have their usual meanings. The data between 1.7 and 280 K are described well with best fit parameters of J 1 = 6.2 cm–1, J 2 = −23.4 cm–1, J 3 = 6.4 cm–1, g = 2.139, and the temperature independent paramagnetism (TIP) of 4.75 × 10–4 emu/mol, R = ∑[(χT)exp – (χT)calc]2/∑[(χT)exp]2 = 8.6 × 10–6 (75 points), as shown with the solid line in and . highlights the perfect agreement of the calculated and measured susceptibility at low temperatures, despite the fact that neither interchain interactions nor paramagnetic impurities had been taken into account. The calculated magnetic susceptibility exhibits a maximum at 0.15 K, well below a value that would result from the size of the antiferromagnetic exchange integral J 2; nevertheless it is one of the distinctive features of frustrated spin systems. The temperature independent paramagnetic term is bigger than usually assumed 60 × 10–6 emu/mol for Cu­(II). This is a common effect in Fe­(III) dimers (TIP ≈ 400 × 10–6 emu/mol Fe, see for example, refs ), but occurs also among copper­(II) polymeric complexes, for example TIP × 106 = [2590, 1800, 1200, 1740], in which the latter three examples refer to the compounds with phosphonic ligands.

elements.content: Honecker developed a 12th-order high-temperature series (HTSE) for the magnetic susceptibility of a trimerized S = 1/2 Heisenberg chain. The broken line in shows the temperature dependence of the effective magnetic moment calculated for this model. Fitting the data (from 10 to 280 K) gave J 1 = 2.9 cm–1, J 2 = −11.0 cm–1, J 3 = 2.9 cm–1, g = 2.144, and TIP = 4.68 × 10–4 emu/mol, R = 6.8 × 10–6 (48 points). Above 10 K these results practically fit in with the calculated values for the Ising model, but for obvious reasons the HTSE model is inadequate at lower temperatures. Individual character of each interaction is the same as in the Ising model, but the values of the exchange integrals are smaller, which is normally seen when comparing the two types of magnetic interactions. The Heisenberg exchange model can also be used, assuming the opposite signs of the exchange integrals (J 1, J 3 < 0, J 2 > 0), but it is unlikely in light of the magneto­structural considerations (see below).

Individual character of each interaction is the same as in the Ising model, but the values of the exchange integrals are smaller, which is normally seen when comparing the two types of magnetic interactions. The Heisenberg exchange model can also be used, assuming the opposite signs of the exchange integrals (J 1, J 3 < 0, J 2 > 0), but it is unlikely in light of the magnetostructural considerations (see below).

elements.content: There are few magneto­structural studies on O–P–O-bridged systems. Correlations of exchange integrals with the dihedral angles Cu–O–P-O (related to deviation of the phosphonate group from the mean Cu–O···O–Cu plane), or with the angle between the O–P–O plane and the Cu–O axis, have been found for groups of similar ligands. General correlations that would be applied to different bridging groups have not been defined so far. Accordingly, it is more convenient to estimate the boundary between ferro- and antiferromagnetic couplings. In complexes containing the bridging groups of μ2-PO3 type, in which the O–P–O bridge has syn-anti configuration, magnetic interactions are ferromagnetic. In the case of syn-syn conformation the exchange integral is usually antiferromagnetic. Such a type of a double bridge indeed occurs in 1 in “dimeric” part of the chain and, in accordance with this hypothesis, the J 2 parameter (Cu2···Cu2) is antiferromagnetic. The ferromagnetic nature of the exchange integrals J 1 and J 3 between the atoms Cu1 and Cu2 may also be justified on the basis of the available literature data. Ferromagnetic exchange was found in phosphonato-bridged μ3-PO3 compound Cu2(H2O)2{O3PCH2N­(C2H4)2NCH2PO3}, with similar structure of the {μ3-PO3Cu3} cluster as 1: the dihedral angles Cu–O···O–Cu are 160°, 71°, and −85°, while the corresponding ones are 166°, 75°, and −98° in 1. Another example of the ferromagnetic exchange was observed in (μ3-CO3)­[Cu3(Medpt)3(ClO4)3]­(ClO4) with an analogous triangular conformation of {μ3-CO3Cu3} (Medpt stands for bis­(3-aminopropyl)­methylamine). However, it should be stressed that a triangular arrangement of Cu­(II) with a central μ3-type bridge does not guarantee a ferromagnetic behavior, because there are known compounds containing {Cu3PO3} unit with ferromagnetic Cu···Cu interactions, but with totally different dihedral angles.
elements.clean_text: There are few magnetostructural studies on O-P-O-bridged systems. Correlations of exchange integrals with the dihedral angles Cu-O-P-O (related to deviation of the phosphonate group from the mean Cu-O⋅⋅⋅O-Cu plane), or with the angle between the O-P-O plane and the Cu-O axis, have been found for groups of similar ligands. General correlations that would be applied to different bridging groups have not been defined so far. Accordingly, it is more convenient to estimate the boundary between ferro- and antiferromagnetic couplings. In complexes containing the bridging groups of μ2-PO3 type, in which the O-P-O bridge has syn-anti configuration, magnetic interactions are ferromagnetic. In the case of syn-syn conformation the exchange integral is usually antiferromagnetic. Such a type of a double bridge indeed occurs in 1 in "dimeric" part of the chain and, in accordance with this hypothesis, the J 2 parameter (Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2) is antiferromagnetic. The ferromagnetic nature of the exchange integrals J 1 and J 3 between the atoms Cu1 and Cu2 may also be justified on the basis of the available literature data. Ferromagnetic exchange was found in phosphonato-bridged μ3-PO3 compound Cu2(H2O)2{O3PCH2N(C2H4)2NCH2PO3}, with similar structure of the {μ3-PO3Cu3} cluster as 1: the dihedral angles Cu-O⋅⋅⋅O-Cu are 160°, 71°, and -85°, while the corresponding ones are 166°, 75°, and -98° in 1. Another example of the ferromagnetic exchange was observed in (μ3-CO3)[Cu3(Medpt)3(ClO4)3](ClO4) with an analogous triangular conformation of {μ3-CO3Cu3} (Medpt stands for bis(3-aminopropyl)methylamine). However, it should be stressed that a triangular arrangement of Cu(II) with a central μ3-type bridge does not guarantee a ferromagnetic behavior, because there are known compounds containing {Cu3PO3} unit with ferromagnetic Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions, but with totally different dihedral angles.

elements.content: The complexity of coordination network and the presence of coordination and lattice water finds its reflection in TGA-DTA-MS traces. In general, TG analysis of the sample in nitrogen–oxygen (80%–20%) atmosphere reveals multiple mass loss steps from 80 to 680 °C (). The first step occurs between 80 and 190 °C. The observed weight loss equals 16.5% which corresponds to loss of eight water molecules (for six lattice water molecules plus two coordination water molecules, the calculated loss is 17.3%). Two next steps occur between 190 and 320 °C and the weight loss is 8.5% which correlates well with the loss of the remaining four coordination water molecules (calculated loss 8.6%). Water removal processes are confirmed by two endothermic peaks at 105 and 210 °C as well as by MS traces (Figure S4). Subsequent series of weight losses starts from oxidative decarboxylation of organic moiety as judged from DTA exothermic peak and intense MS signals of CO2 (peak at 350 °C, Figure S5). Oxidative deamination in turn is evidenced by MS peak at 490 °C from NO2 (Figure S6). Following exothermic processes, in particular at 550 and 630 °C, indicate further combustion of carbon scaffold. The total weight loss of 50.5% is less than calculated value (54.4%), assuming that the final product is Cu3(PO4)2. Nonetheless, the complete combustion of compound may be expected for temperatures higher than 800 °C.

elements.clean_text:
Flexibility of Aminocarboxyphosphonate CP: Dehydration-Rehydration Experiment

Previous experience in the field indicates, that CPs can undergo single crystal-single crystal (or, more generally, crystalline-crystalline), or crystalline-amorphous transitions under influence of various external factors, for example temperature, pressure, light, and addition or removal of specific molecules.

elements.content: There are examples of structural flexibility of phosphonate CPs, whose structure appears to be not dense, as is found for amino­carboxy­phosphonate 1. As shown in crystal structure description section, compound 1 possesses channels running along a and c crystallographic axes which are filled with hydrogen-bonded water molecules. The TGA measurement presented above provided a clue that those water molecules are quite loosely bound to the network of 1, so there might be possibility of water removal upon mild conditions. Indeed, we found that upon dehydration the PXRD spectra are altered (), suggesting that coordination network is distorted due to the loss of lattice water molecules. It was tempting to crystallographically determine structural changes that were occurring; however, despite many efforts, we were not able to afford a suitable single crystal of compound 1 after dehydration due to severe cracking. Nevertheless, the transformation was found to be reversible; the treatment of dehydrated 1 with humid atmosphere resulted in return to the initial structure, although not complete, even after prolonged time of exposure, as judged by PXRD (). Since the PXRD patterns after dehydration seem to have a similar number of signals to that of as-synthesized compound, however shifted to larger angles, we suppose that overall crystallographic symmetry remains unchanged. Moreover, diffraction peaks after dehydrations are noticeably broader, which may indicate that the occurring structural changes are not uniform throughout the structure. If the change of the lattice parameters is caused by movement of a given structural unit, it is possible that in some parts of structure that shift is less pronounced, for example due to strains within crystal; formation of two or more different products is also a viable alternative. Therefore, PXRD measurement of a material in which part of structure can be considered as disordered, gives rise to broadened spectral features. In addition, we have also tracked structural changes by means of ATR-IR spectroscopy (see discussion in the Supporting Information, Figure S7).

elements.content: Our assessment of photocatalytic properties of 1 was conducted using a system consisting of 1, addition of H2O2 as an oxidant and a visible-light source (to confirm that our light source produces only visible light we measured its emission spectrum (λmax = 561 nm), Figure S8). Moreover, three control experiments were used: dyes in the presence of only H2O2 in dark, dyes in the presence of only H2O2 under light irradiation, and dyes in the presence of H2O2 and 1, but without light access ().
elements.clean_text:
Dye Degradation

Our assessment of photocatalytic properties of 1 was conducted using a system consisting of 1, addition of H2O2 as an oxidant and a visible-light source (to confirm that our light source produces only visible light we measured its emission spectrum (λmax = 561 nm), Figure S8). Moreover, three control experiments were used: dyes in the presence of only H2O2 in dark, dyes in the presence of only H2O2 under light irradiation, and dyes in the presence of H2O2 and 1, but without light access ().

elements.content: Upper charts: Concentration changes of methylene blue, acridine orange, and rhodamine B, respectively, expressed as A/A0 value. Blue lines correspond to dye degradation experiments in the presence of H2O2 in dark, red lines correspond to experiments in the presence of H2O2 with visible light irradiation (on plots denoted as hν), magenta plots correspond to experiments with the use of 1 and H2O2 without light access, and black lines correspond to experiments with the use of 1 and H2O2 with visible light irradiation. Lower charts: Fittings of pseudo-first-order model to the experiments involving 1. Insets show absorption spectra of dyes during the main photocatalytic experiment with the use of 1, H2O2 and visible light upon irradiation.

elements.content: The analysis of dye degradation curves strongly suggests that compound 1 indeed facilitates degradation of dyes under visible light irradiation. It is easily visible from enhancement of degradation efficiencies when 1 is used. For example, after 120 min 89% of AO is degraded when compound 1, light and H2O2 are present, but this value drops to 11% when 1 is not used. A similar behavior is observed also for RhB and MB dyes (degradation efficiencies in the presence of 1 are equal to 82% and 90%, but 7% and 12% without 1, respectively). Worth noting is the observation that an enhancement of dye degradation is noticeable when 1 and H2O2 are present, but without visible light access. It indicates that material 1 itself catalyzes dye degradation. This result suggests underlying Fenton-type of degradation mechanism, which involves generation of hydroxyl radicals from H2O2 with the participation of CP, and subsequent attack of those radicals on dye molecules. Keeping in mind the fact that RhB, AO and MB dyes in their structure share dialkylamino structural motif, we suppose that the degradation path occurs through complex known mechanisms, involving oxidation and N-dealkylation of dye molecules.

elements.content: The analysis of dye degradation kinetics indicated that data can be satisfactorily fitted in both cases with the pseudo-first-order model. For all dyes, when 1, H2O2 and light are applied the apparent rate constant is of the order ∼2.0 × 10–3 min–1. Since catalytic processes with and without light access have the same kinetics, it is possible to calculate the “enhancement” of catalytic process, by dividing the apparent rate constant of process under light presence by the apparent rate constant of process without light presence. In that manner, we can see that light presence accelerates 9-, 7-, and 8-fold the degradation of AO, MB, and RhB dyes.

elements.content: In order to check the stability of 1 after photocatalytic measurements we took advantage of PXRD and IR techniques. PXRD and IR traces of 1 before and after photocatalytic experiment are in agreement (Figure S9). Additionally, according to ICP-OES (Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry) analysis of combined supernatants, the mean Cu2+ concentration is equal to 27 μmol·dm–3. Assuming that crystallographically distinct copper­(II) ions are dissociated/hydrolyzed at the same rate, it can be calculated that such a concentration of Cu2+ is achieved after dissolution of 0.7% of the initial amount of 1. Those measurements allow us to conclude that compound 1 does not significantly decompose under photocatalytic conditions.

Those measurements allow us to conclude that compound 1 does not significantly decompose under photocatalytic conditions.

elements.content: Coordination polymers created to date were based on ligands possessing at maximum two different binding groupscarboxy­phosphonates on par with N-heterocyclic carboxylates are among the most remarkable examples. In this contribution we extended the idea of bifunctional ligands to trifunctional ligands, namely possessing amino, phosphonic, and carboxylic groups. A reaction of 3-amino-5-(dihydroxy­phosphoryl)­benzoic acid, designed for that purpose, and copper­(II) sulfate yielded a three-dimensional CP, characterized by an open, layered structure in which intersecting channels are running along the a and c axes. It should be stressed that the layering pattern observed herein is different from that prevalent for metal phosphonates, since the stacked dense sheets of metal ions and ligands are not observed. Instead, two-dimensional metal–organic sheets are bound via copper­(II) nodes. Topological considerations led us to the conclusion that rare topologies such as tcs can be obtained when ligands that possess diverse binding groups are used. This result supplements an existing approach which relies on CP syntheses from mixed polytopic ligands and/or the use of metal ions of high coordination number.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Coordination polymers created to date were based on ligands possessing at maximum two different binding groupscarboxyphosphonates on par with N-heterocyclic carboxylates are among the most remarkable examples. In this contribution we extended the idea of bifunctional ligands to trifunctional ligands, namely possessing amino, phosphonic, and carboxylic groups. A reaction of 3-amino-5-(dihydroxyphosphoryl)benzoic acid, designed for that purpose, and copper(II) sulfate yielded a three-dimensional CP, characterized by an open, layered structure in which intersecting channels are running along the a and c axes. It should be stressed that the layering pattern observed herein is different from that prevalent for metal phosphonates, since the stacked dense sheets of metal ions and ligands are not observed. Instead, two-dimensional metal-organic sheets are bound via copper(II) nodes. Topological considerations led us to the conclusion that rare topologies such as tcs can be obtained when ligands that possess diverse binding groups are used. This result supplements an existing approach which relies on CP syntheses from mixed polytopic ligands and/or the use of metal ions of high coordination number.

elements.content: Arrangement of copper­(II) ions into so-called “diamond chain” enabled us to investigate the peculiarities of magnetic behavior of 1. Magneto­structural considerations and fitting of the experimental data using two theoretical equations (Ising and Heisenberg exchange models) allowed us to estimate that magnetic exchange within chains is dominated by the antiferromagnetic interaction, but ferromagnetic exchange is non-negligible.

elements.content: The structure of 1 was found to be responsive to external stimulus, as demonstrated by dehydration–hydration experiments. The occurring structural modifications, attributed mostly to minor changes in lattice parameters and modification of hydrogen-bonding, were monitored with the use of PXRD and IR methods. Finally, we also demonstrated the multifunctionality of copper­(II) amino­carboxy­phosphonates in a preliminary study of the photocatalytic abilities of 1 under oxidative conditions and visible light irradiation.

cln_elements.content: H 3 APB was synthesized according to a previously reported multistep method. All analytical grade chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Compound 1 was synthesized at ambient conditions. The solution of CuSO4·5H2O (69.0 mg, 0.0276 mmol) in water (6 mL) was mixed with a solution of H 3 APB (10.0 mg, 0.046 mmol) in water (2 mL). The obtained clear mixture was left for slow evaporation for 3 days after which green crystals were filtrated and air-dried. Elemental analysis calcd for C14H34Cu3N2O22P2: C, 20.14; H, 4.07; N, 3.35; found: C, 20.3; H, 3.8; N, 3.5. Compound 1 is not soluble in water and methanol, but is easily dissolved in warm N,N-dimethyl­formamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and N,N-dimethyl­acetamide (DMA), suggesting the decomposition of coordination network. The phase purity of bulk sample of 1 was established by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), since the experimental pattern agreed well with the simulated one (vide infra).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Synthesis of 1 

 H  3  APB was synthesized according to a previously reported multistep method. All analytical grade chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Compound 1 was synthesized at ambient conditions. The solution of CuSO4⋅5H2O (69.0 mg, 0.0276 mmol) in water (6 mL) was mixed with a solution of H  3  APB (10.0 mg, 0.046 mmol) in water (2 mL). The obtained clear mixture was left for slow evaporation for 3 days after which green crystals were filtrated and air-dried. Elemental analysis calcd for C14H34Cu3N2O22P2: C, 20.14; H, 4.07; N, 3.35; found: C, 20.3; H, 3.8; N, 3.5. Compound 1 is not soluble in water and methanol, but is easily dissolved in warm N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), suggesting the decomposition of coordination network. The phase purity of bulk sample of 1 was established by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), since the experimental pattern agreed well with the simulated one (vide infra).

other properties: soluble in warm DMF, DMSO, and DMA

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic behavior of 1 is shown in and as χ–1 and the effective magnetic moment per Cu ion versus T [μeff = 2.828­(χT)1/2]. The susceptibility does not obey the Curie–Weiss law, and the approximate values of the moment and the Weiss constant are 2.13 μB and −19 K in the temperature range 100–200 K, and 2.33 μB and −60 K in 200–280 K. The effective magnetic moment decreases to 1.84 μB at 20 K and then to 1.09 μB at 1.7 K. The M(B) curve increases monotonically with growing field, reaching a value of 0.46 μB at 5 T. At about 4 T a weakly marked inflection point is visible.

Subsequent series of weight losses starts from oxidative decarboxylation of organic moiety as judged from DTA exothermic peak and intense MS signals of CO2 (peak at 350 °C, Figure S5). Oxidative deamination in turn is evidenced by MS peak at 490 °C from NO2 (Figure S6). Following exothermic processes, in particular at 550 and 630 °C, indicate further combustion of carbon scaffold. The total weight loss of 50.5% is less than calculated value (54.4%), assuming that the final product is Cu3(PO4)2. Nonetheless, the complete combustion of compound may be expected for temperatures higher than 800 °C.

Water removal processes are confirmed by two endothermic peaks at 105 and 210 °C as well as by MS traces (Figure S4). Subsequent series of weight losses starts from oxidative decarboxylation of organic moiety as judged from DTA exothermic peak and intense MS signals of CO2 (peak at 350 °C, Figure S5). Oxidative deamination in turn is evidenced by MS peak at 490 °C from NO2 (Figure S6). Following exothermic processes, in particular at 550 and 630 °C, indicate further combustion of carbon scaffold. The total weight loss of 50.5% is less than calculated value (54.4%), assuming that the final product is Cu3(PO4)2. Nonetheless, the complete combustion of compound may be expected for temperatures higher than 800 °C.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

decomposition temperature.condition: 16.5% corresponding to loss of eight water molecules
8.5% correlating with the loss of the remaining four coordination water molecules
